article.title: Wild mouse gut microbiota limits initial tuberculosis infection in BALB/c mice

funding.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases of the National Institutes of Health

article.abstract: Mouse models are critical tools in tuberculosis (TB) research. Recent studies have demonstrated that the wild mouse gut microbiota promotes host fitness and improves disease resistance. Here we examine whether the wild mouse gut microbiota alters the immunopathology of TB in BALB/c mice.

sections.introduction: Tuberculosis (TB) remains a major threat to global public health and years of progress made towards ending TB have been reversed by the COVID19 pandemic [1]. Predictive preclinical models for testing novel drugs and vaccine candidates are required to achieve the targets set forth in the End TB Strategy.
sections.methods: This study was carried out in strict accordance with the recommendations in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of the National Institutes of Health.
sections.results: We used commercially available age-matched cohorts of LabC mice and WildR mice [10, 11] that were generated in the BALB/c background.
sections.discussion: The BALB/c mouse model has been a workhorse in TB preclinical therapy development for many decades, but results do not always align with humans.

experimental_factors.tissue: lungs of animals infected for 14, 28, 56 days were formalin fixed, paraffin-embedded, sectioned, stained with hematoxylin, eosin.
experimental_factors.tissue_raw: lungs of animals infected for 14, 28 and 56 days were formalin fixed, paraffin-embedded, sectioned and stained with hematoxylin and eosin.
experimental_factors.treatment: mtb h37rv (atcc #27294) was cultured in middlebrook 7h9 broth supplemented with 0.05% tween-80, 0.2% glycerol, 10% albumin-dextrose-catalase enrichment (becton dickinson) at 37°c, 80 rpm or on middlebrook 7h11 agar containing 0.5% glycerol, 10% oleic-acid-albumin-dextrose-catalase enrichment (becton dickinson) at 37°c.
experimental_factors.treatment_raw: Mtb H37Rv (ATCC #27294) was cultured in Middlebrook 7H9 broth supplemented with 0.05% Tween-80, 0.2% glycerol and 10% albumin-dextrose-catalase enrichment (Becton Dickinson) at 37°C and 80 rpm or on Middlebrook 7H11 agar containing 0.5% glycerol and 10% oleic-acid-albumin-dextrose-catalase enrichment (Becton Dickinson) at 37°C.

80 rpm or on middlebrook 7h11 agar containing 0.5% glycerol

article.insights_summary: The wild mouse gut microbiota limits initial tuberculosis infection in BALB/c mice by controlling early acute infection better than conventional laboratory mice.
article.acknowledgments: We are grateful for the support of the Center for Discovery and Innovation Research Animal Facility and the Flow Cytometry Core Facility.
